Can we please do PRs that are going to take more than 10 seconds of review out of the druid.io repository?

Agree with @drcrallen about not making branches inside druid-io for these PRs . In fact, I believe, we should "always" create feature/bug-fix branches in our own forks only and send the PR from there. Same will be followed by anyone else making a contribution.

Exception in thread "main" com.google.inject.CreationException: Guice creation errors:

1) Could not find a suitable constructor in io.druid.server.coordination.ZkCoordinator. Classes must have either one (and only one) constructor annotated with @Inject or a zero-argument constructor that is not private.
  at io.druid.server.coordination.ZkCoordinator.class(ZkCoordinator.java:60)
  at io.druid.cli.CliHistorical$1.configure(CliHistorical.java:78)

I'm not sure I understand what this PR is fixing, was something broken? How did it work before?
ah I see, this was broken by #1895
cardinality aggregator uses hyper-log-log, which is a probabilistic approach to counting distinct values. As such it is not an exact count, but a floating point approximation.
Another possible way to count distinct values would be to do a topN sorted lexicographically, and page through the results to count them.
thanks

This looks related to https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/701 and https://groups.google.com/d/msg/druid-development/BSpDmAq-7Jk/_W3q00kkwMIJ

Please post this in the user groups.
@xvrl which libraries?

Fwiw the way groupBy `granularity` and `limitSpec` are supposed to work now is that results are first grouped in their granular buckets (so, one set of groupings for each day if you have granularity "day"), then they are sorted within their granular buckets, then the limit is applied to the global list of results starting from the first granular bucket.

Whether or not this is useful behavior is left as an exercise to the reader.

I agree that it seems weird that the sorting is done within granular buckets, but the limiting is done globally. It would probably make more sense to do both within the buckets or both globally. If they're both local then it acts like your (1). If they're both global it acts like your (2).

@drcrallen I read those issues and they do not look related but I might be missing something. I am aware of how zero filling works and this is not in play here because there is data in all those buckets.

I think the root problem here is that groupBy returns results in it's own special way. groupBY is the only query type which uses the key 'event' in the return. groupBy tries to de-nest itself (unlike topNs) but does not go all the way since it forgets to resort.

> Whether or not this is useful behavior is left as an exercise to the reader.

It isn't
for (1) it would also be nice to change the flatness of groupby and get a nested data-structure like topN maybe with a flag?

@mmcgowan for what it's worth commons-httpclient and org.apache.httpcomponents are essentially two distinct libraries. They should not be conflicting in any way. Are you having any actual issues from depending on both?

@fjy currently the hadoop jars depend on the old commons-httpclient, but maybe we can remove that dependency explicitly unless we overrode the version for some other reason

From the doc, realtime ingestion is using `maxRowsInMemory` and batch ingestion is using `rowFlushBoundary`, though in the code they share the same field, is it intentional or simply because we want backward compatibility?
@guobingkun both processes should use the same config and the docs shoudl be changed to reflect this. 0.9.0 is a good chance to make this change.
Yep, I'm working on it. Testing right now. I've got some questions and will write them down if can't find an answer by myself.

As far as I understand it, in order to implement a separate cache module which works with Redis, we should move `CacheProvider`, `Cache`, `CacheStats` to `druid-common` module, correct?

If so, we would need following changes:
1. Add `server-metrics` as dependency to druid-common thus `Cache.doMonitor(...)` has `ServiceEmitter` as argument (or refactor this to not depend on `server-metrics`)
2. Remove `@JsonSubTypes` from `CacheProvider` and instead register subtypes in `CacheModule` via exported Jackson module -`SetupContext.registerSubtypes(...)`.

I have a problem with backwards compatibility: since I moved `CacheProvider` to `druid-common` I can't set default implementation class in `@JsonTypeInfo` annotation. If there any way to setup default implementation from code or do something else to set `LocalCacheProvider` as default `CacheProvider`?

**UPDATE**: I just looked at code and found that `mysql-metadata-storage` module has `druid-server` as it's dependency. If so, then Redis cache module can have this dependency too and nothing above is needed, correct?

Will I still be able to use `SetupContext.registerSubtypes(RedisCacheProvider.class)` in case that `@JsonSubTypes` over `CacheProvider` is left as is?
@drcrallen i am not sure why getCacheKey should be tested, i have looked all the other filters i could not find any UT for getCacheKey, can you explain more why this is blocking ?
@b-slim I don't think it needs to block the PR but it would definitely be nice if you have time. I am :+1: with or without it. But test coverage is cool.
I agree with @gianm , it is nice to have.
I asked both of these guys to comment as a sanity check and concede to their judgement.
@drcrallen I have added the UT for that function. thanks everybody for the comments
Cool thanks!

Hi @drcrallen, @xvrl, 

I see. 

I've built a Druid metrics to Datadog Druid extension. It depends on Dropwizard metrics, which uses org.apache.httpcomponents:httpclient:4.3.5.

I'm currently on Druid 0.8.1. I had issues with this version. But since the two dependencies are different, it looks like this should be able to work with Druid 0.8.2.

With 0.8.1 it was simple with `extensions-distribution` module. Now it's removed, and I do not understand how can I create a build and include my new extension (resides in `extensions/redis-cache`) into it.
